Single-phase bimetal sulfide or metal sulfide heterojunction: Which one is better for reversible oxygen electrocatalyst? Jingjing Cai a Huijun Liu a Yulin Luo a Yuqing Xiong a Lizhu Zhang a Sheng Wang b Kang Xiao a ⁎ Zhao-Qing Liu a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering/Institute of Clean Energy and Materials/Key Laboratory for Clean Energy and Materials, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering/Institute of Clean Energy and Materials/Key Laboratory for Clean Energy and Materials Guangzhou University Guangzhou 510006 Guangdong China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering/Institute of Clean Energy and Materials/Key Laboratory for Clean Energy and Materials, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, USA Department of Materials Science and Engineering Northwestern University Evanston IL 60208 USA Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Single-phase bimetallic sulfides (CoFeS2) with the uniform structural electron distribution and higher central energy level, affords higher intrinsic activity and faster reaction kinetics than metal sulfide heterojunctions (CoS/FeS). Bimetallic sulfides, integrating the merits of individual components, are ideal structures for efficient electrocatalysis. However, for bimetallic sulfides including metal sulfide heterojunctions (MSH) and single-phase bimetallic sulfides (SBS), it is still unclear about which one has better catalytic activity toward reversible oxygen catalysis and its difference on catalytic mechanism. In this work, we demonstrate a bimetallic sulfide electrocatalyst that could transform from metal sulfide heterojunction (CoS/FeS) to single-phase bimetallic sulfide (CoFeS2) through a facile temperature control strategy. The single-phase bimetallic sulfide (CoFeS2) affords high intrinsic activity, fast reaction kinetics and superior durability toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Density functional theory (DFT) simulations reveal that the (CoFeS2) has homogeneous electron distribution of the CoFeS2 structure, improves the central energy level of d band, and optimizes the O* and OOH* intermediate and efficiently reduces the energy barrier of the reaction rate-determining step (RDS). The assembled rechargeable zinc-air battery is more stable than the Pt/C and IrO2 assemblies due to the excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability of CoFeS2/NC, suggesting that it has potential for use in practical applications. Keywords Metal sulfide Sulfide heterojunction OER ORR Zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction The rapid global consumption of fossil energy, the rising levels of pollutants and greenhouse gases, energy and environmental pressures are driving the search for new energy sources and new ways of storing and converting energy [1–3]. Zinc-air batteries have become an important component of renewable energy systems due to its low cost, environmental friendliness, high safety and high specific energy density [4–7]. The key to the development of high-performance rechargeable zinc-air batteries is a bifunction electrocatalyst that can drive the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during battery discharge and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during battery charge. Currently, loaded noble metal catalysts are used in the production of rechargeable zinc-air batteries. Pt/C catalysts are particularly effective in catalyzing ORR, while Ru-based or Ir-based catalysts are effective in driving OER [3,7–9]. However, their low earth abundance, high cost, moderate stability and poor bifunctional activity for ORR and OER severely limit the application of the catalysts in the rechargeable zinc-air batteries. Accordingly, it is imperative to develop low-cost, efficient, and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts based on Earth-rich elements for both ORR and OER [10–14]. Transition metal-based materials, such as transition metal phosphide [15], oxides [16], sulfides [17], nitrides [18], metal alloys [19] and their mixtures, have attracted extensive research interest in recent years because of their low cost and large amount of savings. The introduction of electronegativity sulfur (S) further enhances electron delocalization in catalysts, providing an effective electron transfer channel for the migration of metal cations to S. The bond energy of M–S in metal sulfides is weaker than that of M–O in metal oxides, resulting in faster kinetic rates of conversion reactions occurring in metal sulfides electrode materials [17,20]. Up to now, many efforts have shown that single-metallic transition metal sulfides have good catalytic activity, but most of them only have a single catalytic activity for OER or ORR and cannot meet the requirements of bifunctional catalysts [21–23]. To address this issue, designing bimetallic sulfide or constructing sulfide is one promising strategy in which the inherent advantages of optimizing electronic structures and the synergistic effect of bimetals. At present, different bimetallic sulfide including metal sulfide heterojunction (MSH) and single-phase bimetallic sulfide (SBS) have been reported. For example, the oxygen-mosaic MSH CoS2-MoS2 nanosheet arrays was demonstrated by hydrothermal sulfide. The tight junctions at the active heterogeneous interface and the excellent electrical conductivity of the two-dimensional structure resulted in excellent electrocatalytic performance requiring only 272 mV overpotential to achieve an OER current density of 10 mA cm−2 [24]. A SBS nickel–cobalt sulfide was presented via a facile hydrothermal method. This bimetallic structure is similar to that of single-phase CoS2, with the introduction of a second metal atom and a change in its lattice constant [25]. Due to the synergistic effect of the bimetal and the multiple active sites, the energy barrier for the decisive step in the reaction process is reduced and the ORR-catalyzed reaction rate is accelerated. In addition, our recent work also confirms that coupling metal sulfide with carbon materials is an effective strategy to improve their performance. Transition metals can enhance the graphitization in the carbon matrix and the interaction between the carbon shell and the encapsulated metal particles to modify the electronic structure of the catalyst [26–30]. Theoretical calculations show that metal sulfide particles embedded in carbon materials promote the redistribution of interfacial charge, leading to the transfer of electrons from the metal to the carbon material, thus enhance ORR and OER activity [31–35]. However, despite of those great achievements have been reported on transition metal sulfides for electrocatalytic applications, it is still obscure which one structure of the bimetallic site is more favorable for electrocatalysis, and why the bimetal sites catalysts with better performance remain unclear. It is unfair to directly compare the performance of the two materials, because the composition, morphology and even preparation method of the catalyst will affect the catalytic performance. Therefore, in-depth understanding of the difference in the influence of bimetallic site catalyst structure on catalytic performance is premised on the controllable synthesis and realization of structural conversion of MSH and SBS bimetallic sulfide. In this work, we demonstrate a controllable strategy to achieve the structural conversion between MSH and SBS through the sulfuration of CoFe/NC. The underlying difference between metal sulfide configurations on oxygen catalysis (ORR/OER) were investigated by combining experimental and density functional theory (DFT) calculation. Theoretical calculations illustrated that the single-phase CoFeS2/NC structure had higher electron density, was identified as the key to the synergistically promoted ORR and OER. Experimentally, the single-phase CoFeS2/NC samples exhibited high ORR (E 1/2 = 0.759 V) and OER (Ej= 10 = 340 mV) activities than metal sulfide heterojunctions (CoS-FeS/NC) in alkaline media, close to those of noble metal catalysts, respectively. The rechargeable zinc-air battery assembled from CoFeS2/NC also showed excellent performance, achieving a power density of 141 mW cm−2 and maintaining stability for 200 h at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemicals used in this experiment have not been further purified. For all experiments deionised water was used. Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O (99%, AR) was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. CH4N2S (99%, AR) were obtained from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory. K4Fe(CN)6·3H2O (99.5%, GR) is gained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. C6H5Na3O7·2H2O (99%, AR) and IrO2 (99.9%) are obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Commercial Pt/C (Pt 20 wt%) content was obtained from Shanghai Hesen Electric Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of CoFe/NC CoFe-precursors are synthesized by co-precipitation method. In detail, K4Fe (CN)6·3H2O (0.528 g, 1.25 mmol) was dissolved in 120 mL of ultrapure water to obtain solution A. Co (CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.61 g, 2.4 mmol) and C6H5Na3O7·2H2O (0.89 g, 3 mmol) and 80 mL of ultrapure water were stirred and mixed to obtain solution B. And then solution A and solution B were mixed and stirred for 3 h. The clarified solution became turbid. Finally, the cloudy solution was centrifuged, dried, and the sample was collected to obtain the CoFe-precursor. The obtained CoFe-precursor was put into a porcelain boat and annealed under argon atmosphere, set at 800 °C for 2 h. After it cooled down naturally to room temperature, the samples were collected to obtain CoFe/NC. 2.3 Synthesis of CoS-FeS/NC and CoFeS2/NC A certain amount of CoFe/NC sample was weighed into a porcelain boat and put into a tube furnace together with CH₄N₂S (0.5 g, 6.5 mmol), and set at 500 °C for 3 h under nitrogen atmosphere. After natural cooling to room temperature, the samples were collected to obtain CoS-FeS/NC. The synthesis of CoFeS2/NC followed the same procedure as above, except that the amount of thiourea was increased. 2.4 Materials characterizations Morphology of the samples was examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, 300 kV, Tecnai™ G2 F30) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-7600F). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique was used to collect information on the crystal phase of the samples at 40 kV, 120 mA and a 2θ angle range of 5°–80° under a Cu K α radiation source. Detailed elemental compositions and chemical states of the samples were collected using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi instrument). Raman spectra were obtained on a Raman spectrometer (JY, HR 800) using a 514 nm laser. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical analyses were all carried out under the same conditions and at the same catalyst loadings. First, 5 mg of the sample was homogeneously dispersed in a mixture of 700 µL of anhydrous ethanol, 300 µL of pure water and 20 µL of Nafion. Then, 10 µL of catalyst ink was added dropwise to a glassy carbon rotating ring-disk electrode, which was evaporated and dried at room temperature, with the resulting electrode being the working electrode. All electrochemical tests are carried out on an electrochemical workstation. A three-electrode system is usually used during the tests, with the Hg/HgO electrode chosen as the reference electrode, the carbon rod as the counter electrode and the glassy carbon electrode as the working electrode. All potentials tested in the three-electrode configuration need to be corrected to the potential at the reversible hydrogen electrode by the Eq. (1). (1) E RHE = E Hg / HgO + 0.059 pH + 0.098 The liner sweep voltammetry (LSV) was collected under a low scan rate of 1 mV s−1 and a speed of 1600 r min−1. And cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were collected under a low scan rate of 10 mV s−1, generally without turning speed. The polarization curves were tested with iR corrected. All LSV curves of the OER are iR corrected. The number of electrons transferred (n) and the yield of H2O2 (H2O2) in the ORR reaction were calculated by the RRDE test from the following Eqs. (2) and (3). (2) n = 4 I D I D +( I R N ) (3) H 2 O 2 \%= 200( I R N ) I R N + I D where n, I D, I R and N represent the average electron transfer number of the ORR, the disc electrode current, the ring electrode current and the collection factor of the RRDE (34%). The performance of zinc air batteries was carried out on CHI760E electrochemical workstation. Zinc foil was used as the anode and gas diffusion layer loaded with catalyst (carbon cloth with geometric area of 1 cm2 and catalyst loading of 9.0 mg cm−2) was used as the air cathode, and 6 M KOH solution was selected as the electrolyte. For comparison, the noble metal catalyst was chosen as 9 mg IrO2 and 9 mg Pt/C. 2.6 DFT calculation According to the first principles, all spin-polarization density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) by means of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation [36–38]. The projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials were selected to give the description the ionic cores [39]. A plane wave basis assembly with 450 eV as the kinetic energy cutoff was adopted to consider the valence electrons. Gaussian smearing to approach setting a width of 0.05 eV was applied to analyze the Kohn-Sham orbitals, partial orbitals occupancies was permitted. The electronic energy was regarded self-consistent while the energy fluctuation was less than 10−5 eV. Also, a geometric optimization was taken as convergent with an energy fluctuation of less than 0.03 eV Å−1. Finally, the calculations of adsorption energies (E ads) were as follows (Eq. (4)). (4) E ads = E ad / sub - E ad - E sub where E ad/sub represents the total energies between the adsorbate and the substrate after optimizing system; E ad and E sub represent the energies of the gas adsorbate, and the origin substrate, respectively. The U correction had been employed for Fe and Co atoms. The Brillouin zone integral uses the surfaces structures of 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst Pack k-point to sample (111) data. The free energies (ΔG) of elemental reaction steps were calculated (Eq. (5)). (5) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE - T Δ S where ΔE is expressed as the difference value between the total energy, ΔE ZPE and ΔS represent the differences between the zero-point energy and the entropy variation, T denotes the temperature (T = 300 K), respectively. For density of states, the Brillouin zone integration was performed using 6 × 6 × 2 Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling for our slab structure. The d band center for d-states had been calculated using first-principles with the metal d orbital distribution. 3 Results and discussion A typical synthesis schematic is displayed in Fig. 1 (a). And the crystal structures of all samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in Fig. 1(b). The diffraction peaks located at 45° and 65° are assigned to scattering from (110) and (200) planes of CoFe/NC, matching well with the standard pattern of CoFe alloy phase (PDF#44–1433). For CoFeS2/NC, the diffraction peaks at about 31°, 35°, 46° and 54° are assigned to the (100), (101), (102), (110) planes of the CoFeS2 (PDF#75-0607). For CoS-FeS/NC, the diffraction peaks at about 30°, 35°, 46° and 54° are assigned to the (100), (101), (102) and (110) planes of the CoS (PDF#70-2864), the peaks at about 30°, 35°, 44° and 44° are assigned to the (011), (102), (211) and (202) planes of the FeS (PDF#89-6268). In all samples, the characteristic diffraction peak of C appears at about 26°, corresponding to the (002) crystal plane, with no shift, indicating that the nanoparticles are successfully encapsulated in the N-doped C layer. Metallic sulfides were prepared in a tube furnace using bimetallic alloys as precursors in a high temperature solid phase process. Typical scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the bimetal sulfides encapsulated in N-doped C layer have been obtained. The samples have a clear cladding structure and the boundaries of the metal are clearly visible (Fig. S1). Fig. 1(c and e) provide a detailed visualization of the microstructure of the CoFeS2/NC and CoS-FeS/NC samples annealed at 500 °C for 3 h under nitrogen atmosphere. Clearly, the carbon shell was in situ formed on CoFe metal particles (Fig. S2), which was caused by the evolution of C species released by sodium citrate under the action of Co-Fe. TEM images of CoFeS2/NC and CoS-FeS/NC also clearly demonstrates its core-shell structure, indicating that metallic nanoparticles are successfully encapsulated in N-doped C layer, similar to CoFe/NC [40]. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy of CoFeS2/NC (Fig. 1d) shows that the characteristic d spacing of 0.20 nm corresponds to the (102) crystal plane of CoFeS2/NC (PDF#75-0607). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy of CoS-FeS/NC (Fig. 1f) exhibits that the characteristic d spacing of 0.16 nm corresponds to the (110) crystal plane of CoS (PDF#70-2864), and the lattice distance of 0.20 nm corresponds to the (211) crystal plane of FeS (PDF#89-6268). The elemental mapping (Fig. S3) confirms the uniform distribution of Co, Fe, S, C, and N elements in CoFeS2/NC and CoS-FeS/NC. Notably, the elemental signals of Co, Fe, S are distributed in more central positions, and those of N, C are distributed in external positions, indicating that the metal sulfides are well encapsulated in the carbon layer. The element N is mainly distributed in the carbon layer, which is well consistent with the TEM results and once again proves the core-shell structure. To further investigate the structural defects and the degree of graphitization, all of samples were investigated by Raman spectroscopy. It can be clearly observed that all samples have two distinct peaks near 1335 and 1585 cm−1, corresponding to the D and G bands of the carbon material (Fig. S4). The D band is the edge or disordered structure of graphene accompanied by activation defects. The I D/I G of samples can be used to evaluate the degree of disorder in sp 2 carbon materials, the higher the value, the higher the degree of defects and the better the electrical conductivity [29,41,42]. The I D/I G of CoFeS2/NC is 0.86, which is higher than the 0.79 of CoFe/NC and 0.73 of CoS-FeS/NC, suggesting that CoFeS2/NC has more defects and higher conductivity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further performed to probe the chemical structure of sample surface and the chemical state of the elements in the sample [19,43]. The survey XPS of the samples is displayed (Fig. S5). The surface of CoFe/NC detects the elements Co, Fe, N and C. The samples of CoS-FeS/NC and CoFeS2/NC also have the element S in addition to the above elements, which corresponds well with the TEM results. For CoFe/NC, the peaks with binding energies (Fig. S6a) of 779.58 and 794.11 eV can be attributed to Co0, the peaks with binding energies of 781.06 and 796.1 eV can be attributed to Co3+, the peaks with binding energies of 782.48 and 797.59 eV can be attributed to Co2+, and finally the position of the satellite peaks at 786.33 and 802.14 eV [44,45]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the high-resolution XPS of Co 2p can be deconvoluted into four sets of peaks. For both CoS-FeS/NC and CoFeS2/NC, the attributed split peaks for Co 2p are similar, except for the peak with binding energy at 779.15 and 793.90 eV attributed to the Co-S bond [46]. However, the peak of the Co2+ peak corresponding to the CoS-FeS/NC was found to have a shift towards higher binding energies relative to that of CoFeS2/NC, indicating a lower electron cloud density in the CoS-FeS/NC [14,47]. In Fig. 2(b), the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p are similar to that of Co 2p. For CoFe/NC (Fig. S6b), with the double peaks at 708.53 and 721.23 eV being denoted as Fe0, the double peaks at 710.86 and 723.74 eV are ascribed to Fe2+, and the double peaks at 713.74 and 726.3 eV are corresponding to Fe3+. Likewise, for both CoS-FeS/NC and CoFeS2/NC, the peaks with binding energy at 707.5 and 721.03 eV are attributed to the Fe–S bond [48]. Notably, compared to the CoS-FeS/NC, the peaks of the Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 orbitals of the single-phase CoFeS2/NC show a tendency to shift toward lower binding energies, confirming the change in electronic structure and the increase in electron cloud density after the formation of the single phase. The Fe 2p spectrum of CoFeS2/NC was deconvoluted into two types of iron, which may be attributed to Fe2+ (711.24 and 724.18 eV) and Fe3+ (714.1 and 726.7 eV), respectively. The high-resolution S 2p of CoS-FeS/NC and CoFeS2/NC were fitted to three peaks with binding energies at 162.8, 164.1, 168.6 eV, respectively (Fig. 2c). The binding energies of 162.8 and 164.1 eV were attributed to 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of S2−, and the peak at 168.6 eV is mainly due to the inevitable oxidation of S [49]. In addition, the high-resolution spectrum of N 1s can be observed with the binding energy of 398.2 eV peak, corresponding to the NC bond (Fig. S7a and b). And the Binding energies of 284.8 and 286.2 eV peaks are also displayed in the high-resolution spectra of C 1s, which may be attributed to the CC bond and the CN bond. The ORR performance of the catalyst was first evaluated by cyclic voltammetry using a standard three-electrode system in O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH. As displayed in Fig. 3 (a), all samples show a reduction peak at around 0.76 V, and the reduction peak for the CoFeS2/NC catalyst is much stronger, suggesting that sulfide has improved ORR performance. The linear scan voltammetry curves for CoFe/NC, CoS-FeS/NC, CoFeS2/NC and Pt/C at 1600 r min−1 are shown in Fig. 3(b), the CoFeS2/NC exhibits excellent ORR activity including an onset potential of 0.84 V as well as the half wave potential of 0.759 V, but slightly below the Pt/C (E onset = 0.91 V, E 1/2 = 0.814 V). CoFeS2/NC affords higher activity than CoS-FeS/NC (E onset = 0.832 V, E1/2 = 0.713 V) and CoFe/NC (E onset = 0.829 V, E 1/2 = 0.735 V). Moreover, the Tafel slope of CoFeS2/NC is as low as 69.2 mV dec−1 (Fig. 3c), which is better than that of Pt/C (84.8 mV dec−1), CoFe/NC (97.9 mV dec−1) and CoS-FeS/NC (85.6 mV dec−1), indicating the faster reaction kinetics and rational structural design of CoFeS2/NC, which takes full advantage of the synergistic effect of the abundant N doping in the carbon layers and CoFeS2, resulting in the superior catalytic activity towards ORR. The ORR catalytic activity was further assessed by calculating the number of electron transfers (n) and the percentage of peroxide generated from the RRDE diagram. As shown in Fig. 3(d and e), the hydrogen peroxide yields for Pt/C and CoFeS2/NC in the range 0.2–0.7 V were 3.43% and 10.35%, with electron transfer numbers of 3.92 and 3.79. The hydrogen peroxide yields for CoS-FeS/NC and CoFe/NC were 12.52% and 33.8%, with electron transfer numbers of 3.72 and 3.27. The results strongly confirm that CoFeS2/NC has an ideal 4e− ORR pathway. In addition, CoFeS2/NC retains 90% activity after 20 h of stability testing, which is superior to that of CoS-FeS/NC (86%) and Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 3f). An efficient cathode catalyst of zinc-air battery should not only have the excellent ORR catalytic activity, but also the excellent OER catalytic activity and durability. The OER performance of the catalysts was measured at room temperature in a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell at 1 M KOH. The OER catalytic activity is first evidenced by the LSV curves (Fig. 4 a and Fig. S8). It can be observed that the CoFeS2/NC exhibits the greatest current density at the anodic potential of all catalyst, even superior to the noble metal catalyst IrO2. The superior OER performance of CoFeS2/NC is further supported by lower Tafel slope (56.2 mV dec−1) and overpotential compared with that of CoS-FeS/NC (61.1 mV dec−1). The LSV curves show that CoFeS2/NC has excellent OER activity, requiring an overpotential of only 340 mV at 10 mA cm−2, significantly lower than the that of CoS-FeS/NC (360 mV), CoFe/NC (370 mV) and even with commercial IrO2 (340 mV) in Fig. 4(b and c). The electrochemical active surface area is an important parameter related to the evaluation of the active site density of an electrode. The double layer capacity of the samples was determined by a simple CV curve [50]. In addition, C dl was 0.34 mF cm−2 for CoFe/NC, 0.59 mF cm−2 for CoS-FeS/NC, and 0.80 mF cm−2 for CoFeS2/NC (Fig. S9), with CoFeS2/NC exhibiting the largest electrochemically active specific surface area in Fig. 4(d), indicating that this catalyst is more likely to expose the active site in the reaction. The charge transfer kinetics were investigated by performing electrochemical impedance spectroscopy at a voltage of 1.65 V. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the charge transfer resistance R ct of CoFeS2/NC is 7.67 Ω, which is smaller than the other catalysts CoFe/NC (14.87 Ω) and CoS-FeS/NC (10.07 Ω), indicating that CoFeS2/NC has the fastest charge transfer rate in the OER process. Meanwhile, the OER stability of the catalyst was tested and the results showed that CoFeS2/NC has excellent stability relative to CoS-FeS/NC and IrO2 at constant current density. The above results indicate that CoFeS2/NC has excellent bifunctiona performance. In addition, we also characterize the catalyst after reaction, and the catalyst still retains its core-shell structure (Fig. S10). XRD result shows that the catalyst is still well corresponding to the CoFeS2 PDF card, indicating that there is no phase change (Fig. S11). From XPS analysis (Fig. S12), the Co-S and Fe-S sites is well-maintained. These results sufficiently demonstrate the structural stability and integrity of the catalysts during the cycling tests. Considering the excellent OER and ORR performance of CoFeS2/NC, an alkaline rechargeable zinc-air battery was assembled to further evaluate the activity of bifunctional CoFeS2/NC and CoS-FeS/NC. The catalysts were coated on a clean carbon cloth of suitable size and acts directly as a catalyst for the air cathode, while the zinc foil was used as the anode and 6 M KOH was used as electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the open circuit voltage of the zinc-air battery with CoFeS2/NC as the cathode material is 1.40 V, the open-circuit voltage of the CoS-FeS/NC is 1.39 V, which is slightly below that of the CoFeS2/NC, while the open circuit voltage of Pt/C + IrO2 is 1.44 V. Further tests in Fig. 5(b) exhibits similarities between the charge and discharge curves of the battery with CoFeS2/NC and CoS-FeS/NC as the cathode catalysts and the battery assembled from the precious metal catalyst, indicating the excellent bifunctional catalytic activity of CoFeS2/NC. Furthermore, the charge/discharge curves and power density curves are shown in Fig. 5(c). CoFeS2/NC provides a lower voltage gap and higher power density (141 mW cm−2) compared to Pt/C + IrO2 (169.8 mW cm−2) and CoS-FeS/NC (119.8 mW cm−2), illustrating excellent rechargeability performance. More importantly, the Galvanostatic charge–discharge cycle tests were carried out at room temperature and 10 mA cm−2 to assess the long-term performance and efficiency of the cells under continuous repeated cycling. In each cycle, the cell was charged for 30 min and then discharged for 30 min (Fig. 5d). Specifically, at the beginning, the zinc-air battery combined with CoFeS2/NC exhibits first discharge and charge potentials of 1.18 and 2.11 V, indicating a voltage gap (Δη) of 0.93 V, which increases to 0.94 V after 200 h charge/discharge cycles, and the voltage gap of the zinc-air battery assembled by CoS-FeS/NC grows from 0.89 to 0.97 after 200 h cycles. Compare this to the Pt/C + IrO2-based zinc-air battery which has a significant increase in voltage gap from 1.09 to 1.39 V after 63 h charge/discharge cycles in Fig. 5(e). The performance parameters of these batteries clearly show that CoFeS2/NC-based zinc-air batteries outperform other batteries. Based on the above experimental results, it is proposed that CoFeS2/NC significantly enhances OER and OER catalytic activity better than CoS-FeS/NC. In order to investigate the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates at biphasic interfaces and single-phase structures, we have used density functional theory to calculate the evolution of the Gibbs free energy of each oxygen-containing intermediate adsorbed on the CoFeS2 and CoS-FeS. It is widely accepted that the ORR mechanism is a four-electron transfer pathway and that the ORR step involves the adsorption O2 to *OOH followed by further reduction to *O and *OH [51–53]. Based on DFT calculations, the Gibbs free energies for the interaction of catalysts CoFeS2 and CoS-FeS with oxygen intermediates and an optimize model are shown in Fig. 6 (a). For bimetallic substances, it is very important which metal site the O2 is adsorbed on. Based on this question, the adsorption of O2 on the Co and Fe sites was first calculated (Figs. S10–S12). For the catalyst CoFeS2, the oxygen adsorption energy on the Co site was the smallest at −1.43 eV, indicating that oxygen is more likely to adsorb on the Co site, so the metal Co site was used as the main adsorption center for the next calculation. The Gibbs free energy changes at zero potential (U = 0 V) and equilibrium potential (U = 1.23 V) are plotted in Fig. 6(b and c). At zero potential, the results show that the Gibbs free energy of all the radical reactions of the catalyst decreases as the oxidation state of oxygen decreases, indicating that the ORR process electron transfer step is all spontaneously exothermic. Furthermore, it can be seen from the diagram that the reaction rate-determining step (RDS) for SBS CoFeS2 is O2 → *OOH, but after changing to the MSH CoS-FeS, the reaction RDS changes to *OOH →*O. In particular, the thermodynamic limit potential of 0.64 V for the CoS-FeS catalyst is much smaller than that of 0.83 V for the CoFeS2, so indicating that the CoFeS2 catalyst has a lower overpotential and a higher ORR catalytic activity. This is a better match with the experimental results. At an equilibrium potential of 1.23 V, the ORR reaction RDS for all samples did not change, and the corresponding ORR limited barrier value for CoFeS2 was 0.41 eV, lower than 0.59 eV for CoS-FeS. The electronic structure changes in CoFeS2 and CoS-FeS were calculated by density of states (DOS) [13,54]. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the continuous DOS near the Fermi energy level demonstrates the metallic properties of the catalyst. Importantly, at the Fermi energy level, the DOS of CoFeS2 is higher compared to CoS-FeS, indicating a high electron density, and Fig. 6(e) demonstrates the projected density of states on to 3d orbitals of Co for CoFeS2 and CoS-FeS. Compared with CoS-FeS (−1.56 eV), the d-band center of CoFeS2 (−0.34 eV) is positively shifted in the single-phase system, so the d-band center of CoFeS2 is closer to the Fermi energy level and has faster electron transport ability, which optimizes the binding strength of intermediates to the catalyst [47,55–57]. The results indicate bimetallic sulfide CoFeS2 facilitate O2 adsorption and influence the interaction between oxygen intermediates and active center by changing the charge density and chemical activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have demonstrated the controllable structural conversion between metal sulfide heterojunction, and single-phase bimetallic sulfide (CoFeS2/NC) exhibited superior bifunctional performance in both ORR and OER. For the oxygen reduction reaction, the onset and half-wave potentials of CoFeS2/NC are 0.84 and 0.759 V, respectively. For the oxygen evolution reaction, CoFeS2/NC has an overpotential of 340 mV at 10 mA cm−2, 370 mV at 50 mA cm−2. Based on the excellent bifunctional performance, while the CoFeS2/NC is used as the cathode of the rechargeable zinc-air battery, the open circuit potential and power density of the battery can reach 1.40 V and 141 mW cm−2, respectively. Moreover, CoFeS2/NC has significant cycling stability compared to noble metal catalysts. This excellent performance of CoFeS2/NC is mainly attributed to the high electron density of CoFeS2, which promotes charge transfer and increases the energy level of the d-band center (DOS), and the synergistic regulation with NC. DFT calculations demonstrate that the structure of the SBS CoFeS2/NC is more amenable to the adsorption and desorption of oxygen intermediates during electrocatalysis. This work presents a new perspective to analyze two-phase interface and single-phase interface structures. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic sulfides, integrating the merits of individual components, are ideal structures for efficient electrocatalysis. However, for bimetallic sulfides including metal sulfide heterojunctions (MSH) and single-phase bimetallic sulfides (SBS), it is still unclear about which one has better catalytic activity toward reversible oxygen catalysis and its difference on catalytic mechanism. In this work, we demonstrate a bimetallic sulfide electrocatalyst that could transform from metal sulfide heterojunction (CoS/FeS) to single-phase bimetallic sulfide (CoFeS2) through a facile temperature control strategy. The single-phase bimetallic sulfide (CoFeS2) affords high intrinsic activity, fast reaction kinetics and superior durability toward oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Density functional theory (DFT) simulations reveal that the (CoFeS2) has homogeneous electron distribution of the CoFeS2 structure, improves the central energy level of d band, and optimizes the O* and OOH* intermediate and efficiently reduces the energy barrier of the reaction rate-determining step (RDS). The assembled rechargeable zinc-air battery is more stable than the Pt/C and IrO2 assemblies due to the excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability of CoFeS2/NC, suggesting that it has potential for use in practical applications.

coredata.dc:title: Single-phase bimetal sulfide or metal sulfide heterojunction: Which one is better for reversible oxygen electrocatalyst?
